item.title: South Africa to Provide $2.8 Billion Guarantee to Transnet
item.description: South Africa’s transport ministry with the concurrence of the minister of finance agreed to provide a 51 billion-rand ($2.8 billion) guarantee facility to Transnet SOC Ltd., the nation’s beleaguered rail and ports operator.
item.dc:creator: Monique Vanek

media:content.media:description: Transnet freight trains at a depot in Gauteng, South Africa.

item.title: German Business Expectations Improve as Trade Fears Ease
item.description: German companies’ economic outlook improved as concern over President Donald Trump’s trade policy eased and an imminent boost to public spending buoyed sentiment.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Commuters in Stuttgart, Germany. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: German Wage Growth Slows Sharply as Economy Struggles to Grow
item.description: German wage growth has eased significantly, and economic weakness suggests future deals will likely be much lower than in the past, according to the Bundesbank.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow

media:content.media:description: PRODUCTION - 26 April 2023, Saxony-Anhalt, Halberstadt: Welders from Verkehrs Industrie Systeme GmbH (VIS) work on a railroad car for the Swiss Federal Railroad (SBB). A major contract from the Swiss Federal Railways (SBB) has gone to Halberstadt. There, 212 Eurocity rail cars will be restored in the coming years. Photo: Peter Gercke/dpa (Photo by Peter Gercke/picture alliance via Getty Images)

item.title: Japan’s Largest Business Lobby Reports Pay Hikes Exceeding 5%
item.description: Japan’s top business lobby reported that workers at affiliated companies won pledges for pay hikes exceeding 5% for a second consecutive year, an outcome that points to continued momentum in wage increases fueled by the worsening labor crunch.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

item.title: Turkey Signals Tight Policy to Stay With Inflation Outlook Hold
item.description: Turkey’s central bank kept its year-end inflation forecast unchanged, signaling that its recent move to a tighter monetary stance will continue.
item.dc:creator: Baris Balci

media:content.media:description: Shoppers in the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul. Photographer: Kerem Uzel/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB’s Vujcic Says Inflation Is Slowly Converging to 2% Target
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Boris Vujcic said consumer-price growth is heading toward the 2% goal.
item.dc:creator: Jasmina Kuzmanovic

media:content.media:description: Boris Vujcic, governor of the Croatian National Bank, during a panel session at the Ten Years Of Euro In Latvia conference in Riga, Latvia on Friday, Jan. 26, 2024. The conference brings policy makers, experts and civil society representatives who played a pivotal role in the introduction of the euro all across Europe and specifically in Latvia. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

item.title: UK Private Sector Shrinks Again as US Tariffs Hit, PMI Shows
item.description: The UK private sector contracted again in May as Donald Trump’s tariffs hit demand from abroad, according to a closely watched survey, raising the stakes for the government’s US trade deal.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

item.title: UK Budget Deficit Widened in April Despite Employer Tax Hike
item.description: UK government borrowing increased in the first month of the new fiscal year, providing Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves little relief from the difficult budget backdrop she has faced since taking office.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of HM Treasury in the Westminster district of London. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

item.title: Why Interest Rates Are Shooting Up All Around the World
item.description: The big bond market selloff.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: The US Treasury Department in Washington, DC.

item.title: Odd Lots: Why Rates Are Shooting Up Around the World (Podcast)
item.description: This week the big story in markets is the selloff in bonds. Yields on benchmark 10-year US Treasuries jumped 20 basis points from last Friday’s low, while the 30-year rate is back above 5%. Meanwhile, 30-year Japanese government bonds clocked their highest yield since records began in 1999. And rates on UK gilts, German bunds, and Australian bonds are also rising. To make matters even more unusual, US Treasury yields are going up while the dollar is weakening (something that doesn’t usually happ
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

item.title: German Private Sector Unexpectedly Sinks on Services Slump
item.description: Germany’s private sector unexpectedly shrank in May as the worst result for services in two and a half years outweighed improvements in the manufacturing sector.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

item.title: BOJ Shouldn’t Act on Surging Super-Long Yields, Noguchi Says
item.description: The Bank of Japan doesn’t need to step into the bond market to take action against a recent spike in super-long yields, as it’s hard to say there’s anything abnormal about the moves, according to a member of the central bank’s board.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

item.title: EU Sends New Trade Proposal to US in Step to Secure Deal
item.description: The European Union has shared a revised trade proposal with the US, as it aims to inject momentum in talks with President Donald Trump’s administration amid lingering skepticism that a transatlantic deal can be reached.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: Containers at Trieste Port in Trieste, Italy.

item.title: JPMorgan Is Long-Term in China Despite Pressure, Dimon Says
item.description: JPMorgan Chase & Co. Chief Executive Officer Jamie Dimon said his firm is committed to long-term investments in China, despite tension between the governments of the world’s two biggest economies.
item.dc:creator: Cathy Chan, Haslinda Amin

item.title: Big Tech’s Model Endangers Economies, Says Varoufakis
India Economic Activity Retains Momentum in May, Flash PMIs Show
item.description: India’s economic activity improved in May despite uncertainty over tariffs, led by a pickup in the services sector and steady showing by the manufacturing segment, a flash survey by HSBC Holdings Plc showed.
item.dc:creator: Anup Roy

item.title: Egypt Poised for Another Rate Cut Before Possible ‘Summer Break’
item.description: Egypt looks poised to make one more interest-rate cut before the summer, when an anticipated new batch of economic reforms may prompt renewed caution over consumer prices.
item.dc:creator: Mirette Magdy

item.title: Vietnam Cites Progress in US Trade Talks, Will Continue in June
item.description: Vietnam says it’s made positive progress in the second round of trade talks with the US, as it seeks to secure a deal to avert a cripplingly high US tariff.
item.dc:creator: Nguyen Xuan Quynh

media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh and Eric Trump at a groundbreaking ceremony in Hung Yen province on May 21.

item.title: Dimon Warns of US Stagflation Risk, Says Fed Right to Hold
item.description: JPMorgan Chase & Co. chief Jamie Dimon can’t rule out the US economy will fall into stagflation as the country faces huge risks from geopolitics, deficits and price pressures.
item.dc:creator: Ambereen Choudhury, Haslinda Amin

media:content.media:description: Jamie Dimon in Shanghai. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Indian Economy Well-Positioned to Navigate Headwinds, RBI Says
item.description: The Indian economy remains resilient to tackle global uncertainties due to its strong domestic fundamentals, the country’s central bank said in a report.
item.dc:creator: Anup Roy

item.title: New Zealand Targets Investment With Budget Tax Incentive
item.description: New Zealand’s government is introducing a new tax incentive to increase business investment as it seeks to lift productivity and stoke economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Withers

item.title: How Low Will Australia’s Central Bank Go On Rates?
item.description: On this week’s Australia Podcast: Host Rebecca Jones speaks to Bloomberg Economics’ James McIntyre about the RBA’s rates experiment and whether it’s paid off.

media:content.media:description: Michele Bullock, governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), speaks during a news conference at the bank's head office in Sydney, Australia, on Tuesday, Apr. 1, 2025. Australia’s central bank kept its key interest rate unchanged, with Bullock unwilling to provide guidance on the May policy meeting as the board awaits more evidence that inflation is moving sustainably back to target in a world of mounting uncertainty.

item.title: Sri Lanka Unexpectedly Cuts Policy Rate to Bolster Recovery
item.description: Sri Lanka’s central bank unexpectedly cut its benchmark rate for the first time in six months, renewing its monetary policy easing cycle to bolster economic recovery.
item.dc:creator: Anusha Ondaatjie

media:content.media:description: A worker pulls a cart with bags of rice, flour, and garlic in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Tuesday, Nov. 28, 2023. Sri Lanka is scheduled to release consumer price index (CPI) figures on Nov. 30. Photographer: Thilina Kaluthotage/Bloomberg

item.title: Singapore Flags Recession Risks After Strong Start to 2025
item.description: Singapore flagged the risk of a technical recession due to global tariff tensions even after its economy kick-started 2025 on a faster-than-expected note.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: New Zealand Budget 2025: Winners and Losers
item.description: New Zealand Finance Minister Nicola Willis had billed Thursday’s budget as a sober affair that would contain “no unicorns, no rainbows.”
item.dc:creator: Ainsley Thomson

item.title: Bessent, Kato Confirm Existing FX Views, Avoid Talking Levels
item.description: US and Japanese finance chiefs confirmed existing currency views and did not discuss foreign exchange levels during a meeting in Canada, sending the yen briefly lower as markets wound back expectations for a more aggressive stance.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, during a House Financial Services Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Bessent said he’s working with US legislators on outbound investment rules for China that would make clear what’s allowed and what’s not.

item.title: Indonesia Set for More Rate Cuts on Growth View, Analysts Say
item.description: An improving market sentiment will pave the way for Indonesia’s central bank to better balance its pro-growth stance with ensuring stability in the financial markets, according to analysts.
item.dc:creator: Prima Wirayani, Eduard Gismatullin

item.title: Ultra Rich Wanted More China Exposure Before Trade War, UBS Says
item.description: Many of the world’s richest family offices were planning to ramp up their investments in China despite the looming threat of a global trade war, according to a survey of UBS Group AG clients.
item.dc:creator: David Ramli, Yoojung Lee

item.title: Carney Says Canada, US Are in ‘High Level’ Talks on Golden Dome Defense System
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney confirmed Canada is considering joining the US in its “Golden Dome” missile defense project, but declined to put a price tag on it and said the talks are at an early stage.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt, Derek Decloet

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, Canada's prime minister, during a news conference after a swearing-in ceremony at Rideau Hall in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on Tuesday, May 13, 2025. Carney's new cabinet includes a mix of familiar names and political rookies to carry out his ambitious economic agenda.

item.title: Why Trump Is Good News for Gulf Nations
item.description: On this week’s episode of Trumponomics, we look at how the US president’s recent trip to the region was a big win for Middle East oil states.
item.dc:creator: Sommer Saadi, Stephanie Flanders

media:content.media:description: RIYADH, SAUDI ARABIA - MAY 14: U.S. President Donald Trump and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman speak as they arrive during the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) Leaders’ Summit at The Ritz-Carlton on May 14, 2025 in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. The council addresses regional stability, defense cooperation, and energy policy among Gulf nations. Trump is on a multi-nation tour of the Gulf region focused on expanding economic ties and reinforcing security cooperation with key U.S. allies. (Photo by Win McNamee/Getty Images)
